newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Air New Zealand profit dives in tough first half.
newsitem.headline: Air New Zealand profit dives in tough first half.

text.p: Air New Zealand Ltd is expected to report a full year profit of NZ$140-150 million (US$97-104 million) after absorbing a one-off NZ$25 million charge, coupled with the likelihood of a leaner second half, analysts said on Wednesday.
Analysts had previously forecast an outcome of around NZ$175 million for the year to June, down from $225.2 million a year earlier.
Air NZ earlier reported a slump in first half earnings to December 31 to NZ$76.74 million from $135.1 million in the previous comparable period, in line with analysts' forecasts.

The company's "project save" campaign would account for a one-off loss of NZ$25 million in the current year, but the short term pain would bring long term gain, with more than NZ$100 million in annual cost reductions accruing the following year.
Robert Bode at Merrill Lynch said the one-off cost would not be regarded as too negative by the market because it suggested some progress had been made.

"It's evidence that they are serious about their cost cutting exercise and we've seen little evidence to date as to what was going to happen. This suggests a little more imminence in that whole area," he said.

Ansett Australia's contribution was higher than expected, returning NZ$16.7 million in the December quarter. But like other Australasian carriers, Ansett International's operations had a tough half year and Air NZ expected it to return a loss.
Air NZ owns half of Ansett in a deal settled on October 1.
David Copley at Cavill White Securities said there were a few positives that indicated a better year lay ahead in 1997/8.
"The balance of probability is that the (New Zealand) dollar is going to be coming down," he said. "The balance of probability again is that jet fuel is at a peak," he said.
Similarly, there was evidence that competition on routes between New Zealand and Australia had peaked over the first half.
"If you remove those one-offs and then throw in the cost savings for Air NZ and Ansett, there are some major positives there," Copley said. Ansett is on a similar cost-cutting drive.
Furthermore, there was the prospect of Air NZ's alliance with UAL's United Airlines coming on stream in April.
Air NZ earlier said it had been a tough operating environment over the six months.
Growth in inbound and outbound traffic went some way to offset the continuing strength of the New Zealand dollar and higher jet fuel prices.

The New Zealand dollar's Trade-Weighted Index gained 4.0 percent over the six months, including a 9.0 percent appreciation against the yen. Over the past three years, the Kiwi dollar had risen more than 20 percent against the U.S.
Those influences had posed big challenges for the company, as they made New Zealand comparatively more expensive to visit.
Air NZ received a tax credit of NZ$593,000, versus a debit of $18.875 million in the previous first half. Analysts said this was probably linked to Air NZ's aircraft leasing and purchase agreements.
In early afternoon trade, Air NZ's "A" shares were at NZ$2.82, down three cents, while the "B" shares were up one at $3.88.
